original_data.question: A 3-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of a productive cough for 5 days. Over the past month, she has had several episodes of watery stools. She is exclusively breastfed every 3–4 hours for 15–20 minutes. She was delivered vaginally at 38 weeks' gestation at home and has not yet been evaluated by a physician. The mother reports that her child is not gaining weight. The mother had no prenatal care. The infant is at the 5th percentile for height and weight. The infant has not received any immunizations. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 155/min, respirations are 45/min, and blood pressure is 88/50 mm Hg. Oral examination shows white plaques covering the tongue and the palate. Rales are heard bilaterally on cardiopulmonary examination. Cervical and inguinal lymphadenopathy is present. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

options.D: Polymerase chain reaction for viral genes

model_response:
The clinical findings of poor weight gain, oral thrush, respiratory distress, and diarrhea in an infant not receiving antibiotics suggest the diagnosis of acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). The laboratory findings of lymphopenia, hypogammaglobulinemia, and the presence of Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia further support this diagnosis. A positive result on a DNA test for the CFTR mutation would confirm the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis. A positive result on a fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test would confirm the diagnosis of syphilis. A positive result on a polymerase chain reaction for viral genes would confirm the diagnosis of viral infection. Karyotyping of the infant's chromosomes could be useful in confirming a suspected genetic disorder.

Answer: OPTION B IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human females as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Individuals licensed to practice medicine.
A cough accompanied by expectorated secretions.
The time for Earth to make a complete rotation on its axis; ordinarily divided into twenty-four hours, equal to 86 400 seconds. This also refers to a specific day.
Every month.
A noteworthy happening that is distinctive in a series of related events.

An increased liquidity or decreased consistency of FECES, such as running stool. Fecal consistency is related to the ratio of water-holding capacity of insoluble solids to total water, rather than the amount of water present. Diarrhea is not hyperdefecation or increased fecal weight.
The nursing of an infant at the breast.
A unit measure of time equal to 60 seconds.
Any period of seven consecutive days.
Aspects of peoples' living conditions that may and can impact people's health and/or well-being. These factors may be physical (e.g., housing quality) or social circumstances (e.g., living alone).
Systematic, objective appraisal of the significance, effectiveness, and impact of activities or condition according to specified objectives and criteria.
Individuals licensed to practice medicine.
Female parents, human or animal.
Detailed account or statement or formal record of the proceedings of a meeting or session. May also document status or progress of an activity or research project.
A person 6 to 12 years of age. An individual 2 to 5 years old is CHILD, PRESCHOOL.
Female parents, human or animal.
Care provided the pregnant woman in order to prevent complications, and decrease the incidence of maternal and prenatal mortality.
A child between 1 and 23 months of age.
Any of the 99 numbered points that divide an ordered set of scores into 100 parts each of which contains one-hundredth of the total.
The vertical measurement or distance from the base to the top of an object; the vertical dimension of extension.
The mass or quantity of heaviness of an individual. It is expressed by units of pounds or kilograms.
A child between 1 and 23 months of age.

Deliberate stimulation of the host's immune response. ACTIVE IMMUNIZATION involves administration of ANTIGENS or IMMUNOLOGIC ADJUVANTS. PASSIVE IMMUNIZATION involves administration of IMMUNE SERA or LYMPHOCYTES or their extracts (e.g., transfer factor, immune RNA) or transplantation of immunocompetent cell producing tissue (thymus or bone marrow).
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.

The act of breathing with the LUNGS, consisting of INHALATION, or the taking into the lungs of the ambient air, and of EXHALATION, or the expelling of the modified air which contains more CARBON DIOXIDE than the air taken in (Blakiston's Gould Medical Dictionary, 4th ed.). This does not include tissue respiration (= OXYGEN CONSUMPTION) or cell respiration (= CELL RESPIRATION).
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A systematic evaluation of the tissues and structures in the mouth.

A white patch seen on the oral mucosa. It is considered a premalignant condition and is often tobacco-induced. When evidence of Epstein-Barr virus is present, the condition is called hairy leukoplakia (LEUKOPLAKIA, HAIRY).

A muscular organ in the mouth that is covered with pink tissue called mucosa, tiny bumps called papillae, and thousands of taste buds. The tongue is anchored to the mouth and is vital for chewing, swallowing, and for speech.
The structure that forms the roof of the mouth. It consists of the anterior hard palate (PALATE, HARD) and the posterior soft palate (PALATE, SOFT).
Abnormal breath sounds (crackles) heard on auscultation, indicating inflammation, fluid, or infection of the lung.
Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.
Pertaining to both the heart and the lungs.
The part of a human or animal body connecting the HEAD to the rest of the body.

The determination of the nature of a disease or condition, or the distinguishing of one disease or condition from another. Assessment may be made through physical examination, laboratory tests, or the likes. Computerized programs may be used to enhance the decision-making process.
